item.title: If She's Naggin', You're Laggin'
item.description: A Vainglorious Media outlet. The first relationship post.
item.dc:creator: Vainglorious
item.content:encoded:
My first relationship post. I know a lot of y'all reading are probably too young to have wives but I am certain youâ€‹ have other women in your life and this applies to them as well.

Women (and feminine people) are socialized to give. Women are the first responders emotionally, the aid-givers mentally and physically. They lift everyone up as best they can and when a load is too heavy for someone they love, they shoulder it. In return, I feel they ask for very little and it would benefit everybody in the situation if we all tried to rise to the occasion instead of asking her to accept less so you can grind. I admit to being at fault here, too. I struggle with finding a that happy medium between working and not working (quality time with family, self-care, etc). But I try to curb my obsessiveness and be good to the people around me by keeping a few things in mind.

Don't act like she's a nag or a bother. Before you get all defensive, I'm not belittling the grind. The grind is essential to creating a successful business. What I'm saying is that you can be more aware of and accountable for the things you're supposed to do for your "right now" life, too. The things that can and should be done while you grind. If the woman in your life has reminded you to take out the trash (or handle whatever other tasks you're supposed to) 5 times and you're still deep-diving in your DAW, you're lagging. And that's just what's real. For one thing, that's your duty. She's not asking you to climb Mount Everest. She's trying to get you to do something you should've already done. For two, you might use 10 minutes taking out the trash but the positive effects go far beyond the time it requires. Simple acts where you're taking care of business reinforce that you're an active participant in your relationship with that woman. It serves to remind her that she's important to you and help her feel valued and validated in continuing to support you.

The idea that long term gain beats short term pain takes over quick, though. And the reason the grind can, in your mind, take precedence over everything because it's so easy to think "when I'm on, things will be better" and daydream about how you'll be able to take care of everybody you love. And that is a noble pursuit, but you can't ignore the other parts of your life in favor of grinding alone. The things you drop so you can grind have to be done by someone. And there's probably a woman in your life taking up that slack so you can do your thing.

Slay dragons!

I'm not saying don't reach for your goals. Nah. Grind hard! Believe in yourself! Conquer your demons and slay your dragons! But sometimes a dose of reality is helpful in remaining grounded and prioritizing for the position you're in currently. Nothing is guaranteed. You may not "make it" as a producer. You may never be wealthy. That's the truth. But the people that have loved you and cared for you will need you regardless and you need them, too. Not only in the future or the past but in the present as well. You need them right now. You can't let those connections die on the vine for the sake of grinding. Nourish your close relationships and cherish those people. Especially the women in your life. She (whoever "she" may be; wife, mother, girlfriend, best friend) is never going to tell your how weighed down and anxious and depressed she is. She's going to put on a brave face for you, laugh at your stupid jokes and love you. She's going to provide the light you use to see the end of the tunnel. Live up to it. Be the kind of guy that can say, "I deserve this." From your wives, your mothers, your daughters, your aunts. Be worthy of them.

Or at least do your best not to have her riding your back about something she already told you to do multiple times. I promise she hates it just as much as you do. (Probably more.) Trust me. I'm married. I know these things.

The Grind

The point of contention is striking that balance where you feel like you're going at a pace that will allow you to meet your goals while being there for your family and friends. I don't have all the answers, Sway. But I know for sure that it's worth it to try.

P.S.: This post is not meant to leave out the men and masculine people. Not at all. If the men in your life are doing the emotional work of supporting you, acknowledge that. But in general, your homeboys, uncles, dads and granddads won't be carrying the same emotional burden as the women. They're not the ones you call when you're about to break down because you feel like it's never going to happen for you. You call mom dukes. You call grandma. You call aunty or bestie. You cry (or don't). You share the heft of your feelings and insecurities about the situation. And they help you carry it. They encourage you. Hell, sometimes they carry you through it, if I'm completely honest. So what I'm saying is: honor them. Honor their contributions to your life and make them feel all the things they make you feel: loved, significant, supported, believed in.

Go. Do it naooo. (Arnold voice)

item.title: Back for the First Time
item.description: A Vainglorious Media outlet. Starting out it can be hard to know which tools you need and which make your life easier...
item.dc:creator: Vainglorious
item.content:encoded:
When you begin studying a new craft that you want to practice, it can be hard to distinguish between the tools you need to get the job done and "convenience" tools that are used make your life easier. It's something I definitely struggled with as a new producer so I want to put this out there for producers that will be new after me.

I have no doubt you have heard the quote, "The journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step." I actually may have paraphrased a little but my point is, you have to start. You can't start the journey if you want to finish another mixing article, top 10 [insert item] list or watch one more tutorial on something you haven't even tried yet. You also can't start if you're trying to save up for that new piece of gear with the amazing tech that you've been following the development of for months now.

And even seasoned craftspeople that don't have everything they'd like to have sometimes need reminders, too.

Tell me if you've seen this before on Snapchat, Instagram, YouTube or wherever you do your social media thing:

Studio monitors - $700

Video monitor(s) - $200+

MIDI Keyboard - $150

Monitor stands - $75

Audio Interface - $300

Desk - $100

Generalization: Pros use outboard gear and other hardware.

Many pros have (or use at their studio) hardware compressors and reverbs, large format consoles and all manner of cool looking gadget; none of which is needed to start. And the keyword there is start. Based on my research and personal experience, the reasons for outboard gear can be condensed to really 4 main things:

  • familiarity
  • workflow enhancement/save time
  • pleasure
  • specialty (getting that "certain sound" or "x factor")

None of that is necessary to begin. Literally. All you truly need is the software (DAW) and a way to hear what you're making. Now you might be thinking how to pick a DAW or which DAW is best. Before you Google that, let me save you some time here: there is no perfect DAW. There's no best DAW. There's no DAW with "the best" sound. There's only the right tool at the right time. What's perfect for you now may not be a fit down the line or may not work for you for a given task.

Personally I use Ableton. I love it and I do everything in it, but I've had to realize that it does have its shortcomings. While it's great for sketching and composition there are DAWs that do a better job with vocal comping and mixing, for example.

So, what's the answer then? What do you need to start? You need patience, resolve and creativity. Decide what you're creating and pick a DAW. Then pick another if you need to; I'm not judging. Find your fit. Discover how you like to work and find the program that offers you the least resistance.

I think about it two ways: you have more time than you have money or you have more money than you have time. If you have more time than money then you should take the time to learn your DAW because it can do nearly anything that can be accomplished with hardware. If you have more money than time then get one or two things that will improve your workflow or efficiency. This might come in the form of improved sound via studio monitors or improved ergonomics in your studio or pretty much anything you can think of that will increase productivity.

Either way, the gear doesn't make the music. You do. Tools are just tools at the end of the day. They're instruments for doing your work. Don't get lost in response curves and specs on rack mount reverbs and other wild internet rabbit holes. Whatever you pick, however you decide to configure things, the sounds that come out of it all come down to you creating and shaping them.

Make the music.

item.title: One Hurdle at a Time
item.description: A Vainglorious Media outlet. This past week, I've been pondering the usefulness of YouTube because it's incredibly difficult to break through...
item.dc:creator: Vainglorious
item.content:encoded:
This past week, I've been pondering the usefulness of YouTube because it's incredibly difficult to break through to a wide audience at this point but I did find myself using it to be seen on other people's videos and kind of start building out a network with other producers. With that in mind, I figure once I've done enough networking, people will start coming to my channel and it might be a bit weird for them to find it empty. So yesterday finds me making my first beat video for YouTube.

And... to summarize, painful is the only word I can think of. Seriously. I opened the video editor, having only used it briefly for looping or chopping shorter videos together. My first thought is, "well, what do I start with?" I didn't have stock footage. I didn't have anything original so I picked an action-packed episode of this anime. Why anime? Well, I'm a nerd and I love anime and I was hoping to create something that would hold people's attention. My beats are experimental; give me a break. Turns out I really have no idea what I'm doing. I'm looking up shortcuts and how to's for simple stuff every few minutes because I am just lost. Not to mention the mini meltdowns from frustration and sleepiness. Don't even get me started on scrubbing 30 minutes of video for good stuff to use; sometimes there wasn't enough and at other times, I had to make some tough decisions on what would stay. I didn't want to use sequences that were too long lest I call forth the mighty Copyright Strike Hammer of YouTube upon myself. Nobody wants that.

Did I mention that it's probably already past midnight at that point in my struggle? The night before I was up until at least 3:30am drinking with my family. My nephew had his second birthday party but it was a Saturday so after the kids went down, the adults elected to have some fun, too. So I'm drinking and drinking. By the time I'm ready to go, I'm toasted. But the night is over. I can lay in my bed and get some shut-eye. Sweet. This was a good day.

Almost. I wake up 9 hours later extremely dehydrated but I say to myself you know I can drink some water, take some Advil and power through it. I've been trying to flesh out this video idea for a week so now it's time for some execution. Needless to say, I am lagging. I barely get anything done. Finally, I go down for a nap and I sleep until like 10:45 that night; maybe later. I get up like holy crap what time is it? The video. I haven't done anything really. So back to working on the video; past midnight already.

I'm getting toward the end and I start to feel accomplished until I remember I haven't even touched the FX program and my video was too short when I added the audio playback. So I'm going in trying to quickly add time without messing up my sequence. Okay, 6 seconds left to fill. I can see the light at the end of the tunnel! And I make it but then I remember I didn't leave room for an intro. /headdesk/

Had to look up encoder settings for YouTube and watch a few videos. Tim was extremely helpful.

Encoding. It's 4am now. I have to be up and at 'em at 9 so I can make an appointment at 10. Probably pushing that back. And just when I think I can relax because I've gotten something done, I remember all the other stuff that goes into a song release. I've gotta write a description and decide on some tags, but not too many but with terms that aren't too broad either. I got a thumbnail to adjust (shoutout Foreign for the template).

I have to say, it was an ordeal. But I'm glad I got through it and I do have my video to show for it plus the experience for future videos. I'll be that much faster next time. But alas, old habits as they say. It's 6:31am (the following day; or is it 2 days later now? I might be delirious) and I haven't been to bed yet. What is my life?

Well, you've suffered enough. Here's the video. Don't judge me. I'm terrible at "typing" my beats but I'm working on it.

There's so much that goes into being a one man operation. If there are any beatmakers (or video makers) reading this, please share. How did your first video go? If you have any questions or tips, definitely let me know!

Until next time. Don't be a stranger though.
